But your opponents are also trying to conquer as much land as possible. Naturally, wild battles can’t be avoided. Only the bravest warriors may move in to Valhalla. Therefore, you’ll need to use tactical savvy when using your men to plunder and steal. Only through successful besieging of villages and reaching other countries will you gain the most victory points and win the game.
25605.name: Walhalla

25606.name: Warbirds in Miniature
25606.description:
Warbirds in Miniature is a game that recreates the epic struggles in the skies during World War II. The game is designed to be played by 2 or more people, although solitaire play is still very possible.

Players select the maneuver that their aircraft will perform from a maneuver schedule unique to each aircraft. Once all the players have revealed their maneuvers, players move their aircraft and then the shooting begins.

The game provides for the use of air/flight stands to be used with miniatures, and is played on a hexmat large enough to hold several aircraft at a time. When planes are damaged, they are marked with either counters or specially made clips resembling smoke or fire.

The Warbirds in Miniature Rules package comes with a 34 page rulebook, 2 double sided sets of charts, 2 double sided sample aircraft sheets, and a CD with over 50 Aircraft sheets covering all the major combat aircraft flown in World War 2. The CD also includes some early Jets for later World War 2 and for use in Korean War scenarios.

25607.name: Housewarming
25607.description:
Housewarming is a simple card game for two to four players. You're trying to fill the four rooms of your house with decor, furnishings, pets, and other miscellaneous items to increase how Stylish, Comfortable and generally Cool your house is.

During the game you can Work (to earn bucks to buy stuff), Tempt Fate (to roll on the events chart), Go Shopping (to look for stuff you (or other players) may want to buy), or Rearrange Furniture (to optimize your house or get rid of stuff you don't want). Your goal is to end the game with the highest average of Style and Comfort with the lowest difference between the two.

Housewarming uses a custom card deck, an events chart, and several dice and tokens. A four-player game takes about 40 minutes to play. Although the topic isn't nearly as relevant for them as it is for a couple buying its first home, Housewarming is appropriate for mid-teens and older.

Housewarming is a free print-and-play game. It is available at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/381/housewarming

25608.name: PerkyGoth
25608.description:
PerkyGoth is a light and silly card game for two to four players. In PerkyGoth, you play cards to accumulate stuff and be seen at events that increase your Perkiness and Gothiness while having the smallest difference between the two.

To play PerkyGoth, you'll need the PerkyGoth card deck (available for free from http://www.invisible-city.com/play/371/perkygoth ) and about three six-sided dice. PerkyGoth is appropriate for early teens on up. A four-player game of PerkyGoth takes about 40 minutes.

25609.description:
In the war-torn land of Warrior Knights, the conflict is far from over. The new Crown and Glory expansion provides contenders to the throne with a multitude of new options, additions, and variants. In the Crown and Glory expansion, a player can actually become King and attempt to prove that he has what it takes to retain the crown! The Crown and Glory expansion also includes Mission cards, which provide players with new paths to victory.

The Crown and Glory expansion features over 200 new cards including:

* New actions that provide mobility and versatility
* Garrisons that help defend your cities
* Town levies that support your armies
* New specialized mercenaries
* A larger Fate deck allowing for bigger battles and new combat and Fate results
* New rules for mercenary Nobles, a new resource, and much more

The Crown and Glory expansion provides Barons with indispensable new resources and options for consolidating their hold over the realm of Warrior Knights.

Expands:

Warrior Knights
25609.name: Warrior Knights: Crown and Glory

25610.description:
[Not to be confused with the 1986 game Chronicles of the Three Kingdoms ]

Published in Chinese in Hong Kong, this game comes in a box, with 520 full color counters, a glossy paper area map of China, 13 pages of rules and 69 cards, mostly event cards, some probably province ownership cards. There is also a double-sided sheet of what looks to be errata.
25610.name: Chronicle of the Three Kingdoms

25611.name: The White House Game
25611.description:
Have you ever dreamed of being the most powerful person in the World? Stop dreaming, and play The White House Game! The winner becomes President of the United States of America.

In The White House Game each player becomes a candidate for the nation's highest office. You have $700 million in campaign funds and you must use your skill and cunning to plan an election strategy that will win the confidence of the country.

25612.description:
This Age of Steam Expansion expands the game to rails under the sea.

The unique aspect of this expansion is its modular nature, as players build the map as the game progresses and have to lay their rail under the sea rather than on land.

This expansion was produced for Essen 2006, and only 180 copies were printed.
25612.name: Age of Steam Expansion: 20,000 Rails Under the Sea

boardgameimplementation: Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization
boardgamehonor: 2007 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2007 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player
2008 Golden Geek Best Card Game Nominee
2008 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2008 JoTa Best Card Game Nominee
2008 JoTa Best Monster Board Game Nominee
2010 Gra Roku Game of the Year
2010 Juego del Año Tico Nominee
2010 Juego del Año Tico Winner
2011 Lys Passioné Finalist
2011 Tric Trac Nominee
25613.description:
Through the Ages is a civilization building game. Each player attempts to build the best civilization through careful resource management, discovering new technologies, electing the right leaders, building wonders and maintaining a strong military. Weakness in any area can be exploited by your opponents. The game takes place throughout the ages beginning in the age of antiquity and ending in the modern age.

One of the primary mechanisms in TTA is card drafting. Technologies, wonders, and leaders come into play and become easier to draft the longer they are in play. In order to use a technology you will need enough science to discover it, enough food to create a population to man it and enough resources (ore) to build the building to use it. While balancing the resources needed to advance your technology you also need to build a military. Military is built in the same way as civilian buildings. Players that have a weak military will be preyed upon by other players. There is no map in the game so you cannot lose territory, but players with higher military will steal resources, science, kill leaders, take population or culture. It is very difficult to win with a large military, but it is very easy to lose because of a weak one.

Victory is achieved by the player whose nation has the most culture at the end of the modern age.
25613.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
boardgameexpansion: BGO Extended 2.0 expansion (fan expansion for Through the Ages)
Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization – Czech expansion
Through the Ages: Spanish Promo Card Set
boardgamepodcastepisode: Board2Death Podcast Episode 5 - Introductions Round One
DdJ 039. Albert Bosch y el Polo Sur. Vlaada Chvatil. Microcharlas
DTS019 - Dice Tower Showdown, Episode # 19
Episode 09 - Online Gaming
Episode 21 - Civilization Games
Episode 24 -- All you need is a Spare Chair at the Doctor's Office
Episode 28 -- A Taj Mahal for Egypt
Episode 29 – Through the Ages
Episode 29 – Through the Ages Part 2
Episode 29w – How to Win Through the Ages
Episode 32 - Top 50, Picks 30-21
Episode 37 - Our 2016 Enthusiastic Seals of Approval!
Episode 4 -- Through the Ages in Under 12 Hours
Episode 47 :: Colosseum Review - 1754 Conquest Review
Episode 5 -- 10 Times 10 Plus 1 Equals 22
ET72: Obama nos espia a traves de las Eras
ET73: Volvemos a encontrarnos Dr. Zrudieyes
Gaming Rules! – Podcast 10
Heavy Cardboard Episode 39 – Top 50 Favorite Games of Right Now
House Rules 67: Interview with Legendary Designer Vlaada Chvatil
House Rules Episode 2: What’s so great about Through the Ages?
Podcast #002
Podcast EP06 – Board Game Arena
Podcast EP10 – Top 10 jeux de société
The Good, The Board and The Heavy Gamers (not talking about Jonathan):  Episode 39 “Three Kingdoms Redux
The Good, The Board and the “Short List”: Episode 40 “Joe’s Top Games”
The Good, The Board, and the Gushy: Episode 11 Vlaada Chvatil
The Long View: Through the Ages
The Messy Game Room Episode 18
The Messy Game Room Episode 30
보톡스(Boardgame Talks) 제49회 - 게임 대 게임_ Civilization vs. Through the ages
제84회 개그세상 - 문화의 중요성

25614.name: UNO: My Scene
25614.description:
UNO Fun with girls' favorite My Scene (r) characters.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The Casting Couch.... uh, I mean, Casting Call card -- ????

25615.name: UNO: Barbie California Girl
25615.description:
Based on the Barbie Cali Girl Line of Toys.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The "Beachcomber" Card - When played the "Beachcomber" card allows a player to instantly discard one card from each color (up to four cards total) to any other player of their choice.

25616.description:
The box says: Created for the material handling division of Allis-Chalmers by Games For Industry, Inc. The description inside the box reads, in part:

A lift truck provides unlimited power, but if it's improperly used, that power is wasted or abused. Only the lift truck driver, the man behind the wheel, can make sure that a truck performs at its maximum capability.

As you play Hi-Lo, you'll see how expert and skillful you are at operating a lift truck ... you'll appreciate why a good operator is a key asset in industry today.

Roll the dice, go around the board, pick up 8 types of cards (design, equipment, job, power, safety, skill, bonus and upkeep), compete for Good Driver tokens, save your company money, and best of all - learn how to operate your lift truck better!

Power Grid or Industria, it may not be, but those games don't offer sample cards such "Save $89. Sideshifter - With this devise you'll be able to pick up and stack loads quickly and accurately", "You have neglected to have faulty brakes adjusted - they failed on a ramp - you dropped a load of TV sets. RETURN DESIGN CARD," and "Save $93. Don't play cowboy. Never speed, always stay alert."
25616.name: Hi-Lo: The Lift Truck Game

25617.name: Korona
25617.description:
Korona is a version of Carrom played in Finland.

Like in Carrom, there is a wooden square shaped board usually less than 1 meters wide. The idea of the game is to hit small round pieces with a bigger piece into corner pockets. In the Finnish version you use sticks to hit the big stone instead of using your finger which makes Korona even more similar to billiards than the Carrom.

The pockets are typically larger than in Carrom but there's some space between the pockets and the edge of the board. Therefore it's possible for a piece to go behind the pocket which can sometimes cause some extra trouble.

During a setup the pieces of each player are placed in a tight row against the wall on the opposing side of the board instead of a pattern in the center. There's no bonus pieces in this game. Because all the pieces are separated according to their color, it's possible for a skillful player to put all the pieces in a pocket with only one strike.

Each player in a three or four player game may play with their own colors instead of forming teams with opposing players.

The Swedish Couronne is similar in that it typically has space behind the pockets and uses cues, but the pieces (usually 15 of each colour) are initially placed in the middle. The game is considered to have evolved from American Carrom early in the 20th century.

25618.description:
From the publisher:

Each player, representing a historical individual in the year 1600, attempts to make his fortune in the Spanish Main.

One player is the Marqués de Guadalcazar, the Spanish governor of Española. He is not averse to dealing in contraband goods with the merchant fleets of the other players.

During each yearly turn, a player bids upon properties and slaves, establishes colonies, and maneuvers his ships for either trade or piracy. He is free to perform almost any negotiation or deal with the other players.

In 1605, the treasure player (usually the Marqués) sails the first treasure flotilla, using either his own fleet, or a contracted foreign one. If the voyage successfully avoids the pirates of the other players, the treasure is divided up as agreed among the collaborators.

The player finishing with the greatest gold and treasure wins.
25618.name: Lords of the Spanish Main

25619.name: Formulon
25619.description:
"Formulon is designed for use in the teaching of basic inorganic chemistry to pupils aged roughly 13 to 16 years. The game package consists of a pack of 100 cards, plus a three-page instructional leaflet; 78 of the cards represent atoms or ions (H, O, etc.), 20 multipliers (two or three) while the remaining two are Mendeleef cards (jokers) that can be used to represent any other card except a multiplier. The basic idea of the game is that pupils have to use the cards to make up chemical formulas."

Taken from the book, A Handbook of Game Design, by Henry Ellington, Eric Addinall, and Fred Percival. Kogan Page, London: 1982.

25620.name: Monopoly: Glasgow
25620.description: An edition of the commercially successful board game, Monopoly. This edition takes in the Scottish city of Glasgow. Popular and well known Glaswegian areas are for sale including Glasgow Central Railway Station, the Burrell Collection and Hampden Park football ground.

25621.description:
The Gloom: Unwelcome Guests expansion adds one player and 55 cards to the game. Here is a description of the expansion from the publisher:

In the Gloom card game, you make your eccentric family of misfits suffer the greatest tragedies possible before helping them pass on to the well-deserved respite of death. Just mix the 55 transparent cards in this new set together with your copy of Gloom to add morbid new Modifiers, Events, and Untimely Deaths, and a new family - the malodorous Malone mob - including The Broken Arms Hotel as a Residence card to use with the Unhappy Homes expansion. When Boils Malone brought his family overseas to “get away from the heat,” he wasn’t expecting quite so much rain!

Adding an extra level of strategy, new persistent effect icons on cards allow their special effects to continue to be active even if covered by another card. A persistent effect ends only when the attached character is killed.

Also inside are five Unwelcome Guest cards. Deal one or more face up to the table’s center at the start of the game. Guests “follow” the card types noted on them; no matter where it currently is, a living Guest immediately moves to join the family of the character on which one of its “trigger” cards is played. All its Modifiers are moved with it, and it’s considered a member of that family until it moves again. This may delay the game’s end if a final play draws a Guest to the near-winner’s family.
25621.name: Gloom: Unwelcome Guests

25622.name: Spot the Intro DVD Edition
25622.description:
This game is an off-shoot from the original Board Game version with CDs.

The DVD comes with a thousand well-known tunes, which cover famous hits from the last 50 years, plus Musicals, TV & Film themes and some Classical music, too.

The DVD is instantly ready to play, and there are picture rounds in which you have to name the bands, the singers and the musician.

It can be a team game where everybody gets a chance to take part at the same time or you can play as individuals, trying to recall where you've heard the tunes or seen that face before!

Contents:

DVD with over 2,000 clips of music and pop-artist pictures
Score Pad with Master & Team Score sheets
Answer Rule Book
Pencils
Flip Score Charts

25623.description:
In Mmm...Brains! you and your zombie friends roll the dice and rush to collect as many brains as possible. After all the brains are gone, roll the dice and force your opponents to drop their precious brains. Be the last with any brains and win the game! Each game comes with: 5 Custom Dice, 5 Player Cards, Rules and 50 custom sculpted BRAINS!

MMM Brains
25623.name: Mmm ... Brains!
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 32 - Knizia on Ingenious Puzzles, plus Dragon Parade, Escalation and Mmm...Brains
Meeples & Miniatures - Episode 3

25624.name: Mutual Fundz
25624.description: Each player builds a portfolio of mutual funds through purchase, sale, and trade. Players roll dice and move around the board, landing on squares and drawing cards that make funds in their portfolios rise and fall. Some cards allow players to swap their poor funds for the good funds of others, or cause various catastrophes in their funds. Players can also earn bonuses for being the first to traverse each quarter of the board, or for accumulating all five funds in any of the six fund sectors. After four quarters of the board have been completed (eight quarters in the two player version), the player with the highest value of funds plus cash wins the game.

25625.name: Snakebite
25625.description:
This is a press your luck game with components based on a Native American game called the Stick Game. With the new rules it is similar to the dice game Pig Dice.

Players toss the sticks. Each snake that is shown on the result of a toss counts as a point. A player can stop tossing and store those points or toss again. If the player ever gets a "snakebite" (two snakes shown and the man), all points from that turn are lost.

25626.name: Enterprise: the Elite Trading Game
25626.description:
Enterprise is a real estate trading game, with some resemblance to Monopoly, but with elaborations. While it is designed in Australia, and uses a few Australian expressions, the content and theme are not noticeably Australian.

The playing area is a simulation of a planned city, divided into two zones : an inner Residential ring and an outer Industrial ring. The play proceeds on a circular track, with each ring containing a series of “sites”, of which two aggregate to a “subdivision”.

The ultimate objective is to “evenly develop” as many of these sites as possible, without going broke !

The Residential zone can be developed by building Cottages, Mansions, and Flats(apartments), while the Industrial zone is available for a variety of uses, represented by card “shares”( stocks). It is NOT necessary to land on a particular site to purchase it.

Players alternate between each ring according to dice throws, and pay penalties for landing on other Players’ sites. Several spaces mandate change of zone. Movement is subject to considerable randomization.

Each player receives an initial land allocation of two “subdivisions’ (two sites each of Residential and Industrial) ; plus a cash “float”. Players proceed to buy development items, initially from the bank. The pool of available items is limited, to induce competition.

The inventory comprises: Cottages 14, Mansions 10, Flats 6 ( total 30). The space available to place these items totals 24. Prices range from a low of $100 for “Cottages” to $400 for a “share” in the “Electronics” factory. More expensive items eventually provide a disproportionately higher return, but may be too expensive in the beginning of the game.

Players are able to increase the value of their holdings by increasing the capital investment on each site from a single unit up to two units and/or more valuable buildings and upgraded shares. Any site must contain only identical items, but any subdivision may contain a mix ( eg cottages and mansions on adjacent sites; or, say, “railway” shares next to “glass works”).Various bonuses accrue when sites are “double developed” and/or when sites are “evenly developed”.

These development items are available initially from a bank, but soon become tradeable between Players. Players short of cash for Landing fees may even have to trade/sell at “distress” prices.

When all a Player’s sites are “evenly developed”, Players can attempt to buy more
(vacant) land, from the bank only.

The game has several unusual features:
1. “stock’ ( houses, shares etc) can be moved from one site to another, or even “off board” until required again.
2. un-developed sites attract no landing fees (unlike Monopoly)
3. there is some limited scope for trading of rationed items above their “bank price”, as Players seek to establish “double developed” sites
4. The amount of cash available to any Player for buying at any one time is limited by certain arbitrary rules.

Possible faults :
1. The supply of in-coming cash seems too small compared to the amount leaving the Game via random penalties.
2. Arbitrary limits on Players ability to spend seem unnecessary.
3. The Game relies on a “Special Lucky Seven” rule that is easy to overlook !
4. The Rules are numbered, thus easy to reference; they are not however, arranged intuitively, and contain a few cryptic passages!

25627.name: SeaRovers
boardgamepublisher: History In Action Game (The Galactic Attic)
25627.description:
Grab your cutlass and be prepared!
SeaRovers™ puts you in command of the most notorious cutthroats that ever roamed the Spanish Main. Fame and fortune await as you take on the role of freebooters and filibusters such as Blackbeard, Bartholomew Roberts, Francois l’Olonnais, and Sir Henry Morgan. You'll build infamous buccaneer and pirate vessels, assign crew and weapons, then set sail on the high seas of the Caribbean in search of prey and plunder.

SeaRovers is an epic board filled with adventure, history, combat, greed and strategy. The game faithfully represents the Age of Buccaneers and the Golden Age of Pirates, and is designed with artwork and components that immerse players in a detailed atmosphere of true piratical adventure. The mechanics of the game combine; card-play and hand-management, a pick-up and delivery system that at times can be wrought with peril, and strategic planning on a hex-based map with accurate locations of historical buccaneer and pirate attacks.

The game-play in SeaRovers involves the thoughtful planning of objectives while weighing risk vs. reward by analyzing the probabilities of attacks and combat. The basic game is simple enough for casual gamers, yet the game also provides optional advanced rules with rich features that will satisfy gamers that enjoy heavier games with challenging tactical decisions and a heightened level of realism.

SeaRovers is a game for one to four players developed to accommodate multiple playing styles and reward players that carefully contemplate their course and actions.

25628.name: Tranquility Base
boardgamepublisher: History In Action Game (The Galactic Attic)
25628.description:
Welcome to TRANQUILITY BASE™, The Exciting Game of America’s Race to the Moon™. This comprehensive game is the new and expanded second edition of Moonshot the Game™, called “One of the Coolest New Board Games” by Inquest Magazine and awarded “Best New Family Game” by GAMES Magazine.

TRANQUILITY BASE recreates the fascinating story of mankind’s greatest adventure—the Apollo voyages to the Moon. No trivia, no dice...Just real men, machines and two chimpanzees. NASA projects Mercury, Gemini and Apollo provide the backdrop as players are put in command of the Space Race. Each landmark event, pioneering mission, heart-pounding crisis and incredible machine is represented by a playing card. Players use these cards and a supply of fuel counters to complete historic NASA space missions in a race to be the first to land on the Moon.

To complete each mission, you must use your fuel supply to assemble the correct equipment, launch the mission and move your playing piece to the corresponding mission patch on the game board. This completes the mission, you receive a replica mission patch and gain a fuel bonus. During the game you can take advantage of special wild, history and instant cards. These represent historic events in space history and can be played to speed your progress or hinder your opponents. After completing the required number of missions, be the first to land on the Moon and win the game. TRANQUILITY BASE has a wealth of detail and flavor for the space enthusiast. If you're big on space travel or really enjoy space history, this game is a must. And it's expandable too!

25629.name: Embargo
25629.description:
Embargo is an abstract strategy game for 2 or 4 players. You begin the game with your six pieces arranged in a triangle on one corner of a chess board. Pieces rest on the points of the grid, not the spaces.

On your turn, you can move one of your pieces any distance in a horizontal or vertical direction, like a rook in chess. Your goal is to move all of your pieces to the opposite corner of the board.

When two pieces of the same color share the same line without any other colored pieces between them, imagine an invisible wall extending between those two pieces. You cannot move your piece through any wall nor can you land a piece on a point currently occupied by a wall. (This rule applies even if you're trying to pass through a wall you created!)

Because walls apply equally to all players, it becomes dangerous to be too defensive. A diplomatic atmosphere emerges from these simple mechanics as your pieces dance around the board, avoiding walls and building new walls of their own.

From the Luchacabra website:

This elegant abstract board game is deceptively simple. Move your pieces like chess rooks, trying to get to the opposite corner of the board. Uninterrupted lines between your pieces form imaginary walls that no pieces, not even your own, can cross. That’s it! Embargo is a strategic game of territorial control and sharing.

25630.description:
The Island of Lost Spells is a programmed adventure using Dark City Games Legends of the Ancient World rule set. These rules provide gameplay very similar to that of Melee and Wizard from Metagaming. This adventure is compatible with those games as well.

Battles are fought with counters on a hex map that is included with the game.

This series of games can be played one of three ways: Game Mastered, "semi-solitaire" (group play with no GM), and solitaire.
25630.name: Legends of the Ancient World: The Island of Lost Spells

25631.name: Legends of the Ancient World: The Crown of Kings
25631.description:
The Crown of Kings is a programmed adventure using Dark City Games Legends of the Ancient World rule set. These rules provide gameplay very similar to that of Melee and Wizard from Metagaming. This adventure is compatible with those games as well.

Battles are fought with counters on a hex map that is included with the game.

From the Publisher: "The Crown of Kings! The ancient symbol of ruler ship from the legendary Federative Empire, said to have ruled this land in the misty past. Some say that when the Crown is again brought to light, and worn by one both steadfast and strong, the Empire will rise again. That is the work, perhaps, of generations of imaginations, but the Crown of Kings would be a prize indeed."

25632.description:
The Sewers of Redpoint is a programmed adventure using Dark City Games Legends of the Ancient World rule set. These rules provide gameplay very similar to that of Melee and Wizard from Metagaming. This adventure is compatible with those games as well.

Battles are fought with counters on a hex map that is included with the game.

From the Publisher: "When assassins stage a brutal raid at the Temple of the Sun Goddess, you answer the call for assistance. But as you track the raiders through the sewers beneath the city, an ancient horror wakens from its timeless sleep."
25632.name: Legends of the Ancient World: The Sewers of Redpoint

25633.name: Das Warnemündespiel
25633.description:
A Monopoly clone set in the coastal town of Rostock-Warnemünde, Germany. As the game has been developed by a local radio station and sponsored by various Warnemünde entrepreneurs, the players have to acquire and trade company shares instead of streets.

The penalties for players ending their move on an already occupied field only increase with the number of company shares with identical colors; the concept of additional buildings such as hotels been dropped. Instead, this game features profit and loss statements that are triggered by certain fields. They change share values, resulting in players paying money into or getting money from a money pool. There are also pool cards triggering the profit and loss statements of shares of one color.
Another non-Monopoly concept is that of shortcut fields (Warnowtunnel, Scandlines ferry) that allow the players to quickly move over a section of the board for a small fee.

25635.description:
Island War is a game of skirmishes in the Pacific Theater of the Second World War. You control Squads of Japanese and
Americans, machine guns, flamethrowers, and Leaders as you fight battle on Iwo Jima, and other islands.

Each Island War hex represents 25-40 meters of terrain, and the turns depict from a few seconds to several minutes of action. The counters represent single characters (Leaders), Squads of men, Weapon Teams, Support Weapons and various administrative markers.

Squads have three figures on the front of the counter and two on their back/reduced side. Leaders have a face on both the front and the back of the marker, and weapons teams have 2-3 men and the weapon’s nomenclature, such as Type 92, on a larger, 3/4" counter. Collectively, Squads, Leaders, and Weapon Teams are called units. A unit’s reduced side is indicated by lighter color. There are also administrative markers, labeled Move, Fire, etc, used to assist in playing, and finally markers that represent Support Weapons, such as the USMC’s BAR, (that must be crewed by Squads).

The game on PDF file contains the rules, counters, and two map sheets. It comes with two scenarios, both from the Iwo Jima campaign.
25635.name: Island War

25636.name: Henry Ford's River Rouge
25636.description: This educational game recreates Henry Ford's immense industrial complex outside of Detroit. Players or teams compete to most efficiently produce Model A automobiles, while overcoming difficulties in production and management. The game was produced in cooperation with the Henry Ford Museum & Greenfield Village.

25637.name: Sweepstakes
25637.description: Sweepstakes is a simple game of horse racing in the 18th century. Both oval track and steeplechase racing events may be wagered upon. The game also includes a brief history of horse racing.

25638.name: Motor Chase Across London
25638.description: This is a roll and move game featuring a car chase through the London streets. A lead car and 4 pursuit cars are represented by small, cast metal, car model playing pieces. Game has a similarity to Scotland Yard but with much more simple rules.

25639.name: Golfette
25639.description: Board game based on Golf. Nine hole course on the board is played twice. The course has all the usual hazards, bunkers, water hazards, out of bounds, and rough. Recovery from hazards is achieved using two packs of cards, distance and direction of shots from a chosen club determined by two different size dice. The game can be played by up to 8 players in pairs or two to four singles.

25640.name: Tumble Numble
25640.description:
The Cross-Number Game - Portable Cube Edition

A version of Scrabble with non-standard numbered dice, red rolling cup, scorepad and timer.

"THE OBJECT:
To compete for high score while placing numbered cubes in sequences that are divisible by three.

TO BEGIN:
Each player tumbles a cube.
The player with the highest value starts.
To start each round: place all eleven cubes in the Tumble Numble Tumbler,
the first player then tumbles five cubes into his hand (without looking at their values)
and passes these five cubes to the player on his left.
This occurs only at the beginning of each Round.
The remaining six cubes he tumbles upon the table and arranges as many as possible in a valid sequence.
After declaring the score, he passes the tumbler along with any cubes he was unable to use, to the player on his left.
The second player places his five cubes along with any unused cubes from the preceding player into the tumbler,
tumbles them upon the table and arranges his cubes as an extension or in cross-word fashion to the previously
played sequence.

BASIC STRATEGY
Create sequences that take best advantage of Bonus Cubes, particularly the double and triple sequence cube
so that the cube will be available to either you or your partner on succeeding plays.
Avoid making bonus cubes available to opponents.
Remember the Zero Cube freezes further play and is of considerable strategic value in this respect."

Components:
1 Tumbler cup
1 Scorepad
1, 3-min. sand timer
Rules
1 Red cube: 1, 2, (3), 4, (5), 7
1 Blue cube: 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8
1 Green cube: 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9
8 Black cubes:
0, 1, 2, 7, 8, 9
blank, 0, 1, 7, 8, 9
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

25642.name: Kasl
25642.description:
It is the Middle Ages, the era of seigniorial order, when decentralization of the structures of royal power has created a subtle balance between the Lords. The castle no doubt represents the new order best. By appropriating land, Lords make war on other Lords and banish them from their kingdoms. Calling on villagers and peasants the Lords mount armies worthy of their kingdoms. Defenses are fortified and new attack forces enter into play, such as the terrifying cavalry and destructive war machines.

You can resist the enemy by building new strongholds. But watch out for the ever-present black plague; it can hit at any time, eliminating your armies and hindering the expansion of your kingdom. You will need to request the services of a Lord to provide moral support to your army.

As the Lord of your kingdom, you will be called upon to make difficult choices throughout the game. Raising an army, recruiting new troops, building new defenses, fortifying your city and laying siege to your enemy are some of the challenges ahead. By building a diversified army and carrying out secret missions, you can amass great power to become Lord of the entire realm.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee
2007 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2007 International Gamers Awards - General Strategy; Multi-player Nominee
2007 Nederlandse Spellenprijs Nominee
2007 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Familien Recommended
2007 Spiel des Jahres Nominee
2008 JoTa Best Light Board Game Nominee
25643.description:
Arkadia is a game about building the city and castle of Arkadia.

Players use builders, cards, workers, and neutral workers to build houses in Arkadia. Houses are built with the seal of one of 4 families; this family gave the building order and will get the building player its seal.

These seals can be changed for victory points. But seals are subject to changing values. The growing castle (every time a house is built, players also build on the castle) has the 4 seals on it as well, which decides the value of each seal. The castle is also the game's timer: once the second layer is built, the last round starts. The player with the most gold wins.

Released: Essen 2006.
boardgameversion: Ravensburger German edition with SdJ logo
25643.name: Arkadia
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 30 - Space Dealer, On The Underground, Baumeister von Arkadia
Exploring Games, Episode 12: My Top 11 (or more) Favorite Game Mechanics
The Spiel #32 - Spiel des Schpiel

25644.description:
From the Manufacturer:

GEIST Junior takes young players on a wild journey to meet the 13 adorable Pet Geists. It is the most fun and imaginative children's game yet! GEIST Junior is the first combination puzzle and board game, with 4 different puzzles for 4 times the fun!
25644.name: Geist Junior

25645.description:
Verflixxt nochmal! is "Die 1. Erweiterung" (the first expansion) for Verflixxt! (That's Life!).

It adds:

pieces for two more players (3 white, 3 purple)
4 more tiles for the track
an effigy of Flixxy, the bird
4 discs (+1 through +4)
10 worm tiles
an action die.




Expands:

Verflixxt! (That's Life!)
25645.name: Verflixxt nochmal

25646.name: M.A.C.: Modern Armored Combat
25646.description: Miniature rules for modern armored combat. Rules are design for playability with emphasis on keeping game play moving. Game rules include statistics on tanks from many different countries including USA, Israel, France, Germany, Britain, China and Russia. System is designed for use on 1/285 scale but can also be scaled to 10mm, 15mm and 20MM.

25647.name: Kings Keep
25647.description:
Kings Keep is a card-based strategy game for 2-8 players where they wrestle over lands, form alliances, trade for vitally needed cards and go for full-on conquest.

Try to hold the best land cards at the end of the hand while fending off archers, knights and peasants with your own carefully prepared defensive lines.

Walls can protect you somewhat but watch out for siege engines. There are also spies about.... If attackers create a gap in your defenses your lands are sure to be captured.

Simple design with enough strategy to keep you guessing and plotting. With a limited hand size, good timing and clever placement is essential.

25648.description: In this British card game, likely inspired by the children's song, everyone tries to get 10 teddy bears to come to his/her picnic. 54 cards show teddy bears, honey pots, food items and other objects.
25648.name: Teddy Bear's Picnic

25649.name: Jambo: The World Game
25649.description:
From the Rules: Object - Your goal is to become a Citizen of the World by moving around the board, answering questions, and completing challenges. The first person to make it around the world wins. -Contents- Game board, 3 sets of cards: Question, Action & Wild, Six playing pieces, 1 Die.

A Trivia game with players moving around a map of the world trying to get to the end first, with some variation such as a group questions that move everyone forward and Action & Wild card options that have you do other things like say "Goodbye" in three different languages or leapfrog over the next player pawn.

Developed with funding from the IBM Global Work/Life Fund and the AT&T Family Resource Program. Jambo was created with the help of Educators for Social Responsibility, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

25650.description:
Colin Meads Rugby Trivia New Zealand is a rugby board game designed for 2-6 players. It has 1,500 adult questions, 300 beginners questions and 300 childrens' questions so is great for the whole family!

How to play
Throw the die and move the number thrown along the board. Depending on what square is landed on as to whether a question is asked or not. If a question is asked players move ahead one space if correct and back 2 spaces if incorrect. There are penalty's bonus spaces and second chances.
Winner of the game is the one who gets to the finish first.
25650.name: Rugby Trivia: Colin Meads

boardgamepublisher: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)
25651.description:
Supplement to "A Good Day to Die", Skirmish-Level Miniature rules.

This is a very extensive supplement detailing many of the Indian tribes of eastern United States during the period 1690-1815. It also includes sections to support French and Indian War period.
25651.name: War in the Forest

25652.name: A Good Day To Die
boardgamepublisher: HLBS Publishing (The Honourable Lead Boiler Suit Company)
25652.description:
Skirmish-Level Miniature rules for the "Old West" and Turn of the Century Period.

It is currently in the 2nd Edition rule book.

Figures are organized into various classes: Killers, Warriors, Soldiers, Civilians, and Rabble. Each figure is activated through the motivation of leaders. Priority of action is variable in accordance with class. Movement is likewise variable.

25653.name: Cosmic Attack
25653.description:
In this game by Roberto Fraga you are an alien from the planet Krakton. You've landed on planet earth, simply because you love the blue planet and its inhabitants. The object of this journey: a search for souvenirs.

By use of your legs, your breathing, your voice, your elbows and whatnot, you try to complete your mission. The challenges created by this game will seriously cause insane game nights.

Game art by Sofi, ages 8 and up, published: Essen 2006.

25654.description:
You can count on cool bikes and fast tracks, because the Unbesiegbaren Sieger (Unbeatable Victors) have challenged the Wilden Kerle (Wild Boys) to a bicycle race. Round after round, the bikes race over the track, but everywhere, the low tricks of the opponents lurk. Using honey-feather-cannons, roller-bicycles and other mean things they try to push the competition out of the race. Every inch counts, and so a lot of riders lose the overview in the all-out trick-cards duel.

The game consist of: 1 Gameboard, 20 Pawns, 10 Wilde Fußballkerle, 10 Unbesiegbare Sieger, 1 measuring stick, 20 trick cards, 10 power chips, 1 cloth bag.
25654.name: Die wilden Fussballkerle: Das Rennen

25655.name: Country Yossi and the Shteeble-Hoppers game
25655.description:
Mazel Tov!! You have been voted "Meshulach" (fund raiser" for your SHTEEBLE! You must visit all 8 neighborhood Schteebles (4 in outer circle and 4 in inner circle), collect pledges, and return to your Home Schteeble in the inner circle. After the first two players have returned home, both players count their money pledges and the one that has the most wins.

Players spin the spinner, move around, win money from the "Pushka," draw cards and learn loads of Yiddish! Cards include "Flatbush Shteeble celebrates a "Siyum Shas," "Stare one player in the eye and say in a high, squeeky voice 'I vant Lukshin Keegel and I vant it RIGHT NOW!' That player pays you $100", "Name all the Jewish months and get $100 from bank," and "Moishe Shmeel tied your tzizzis to your chair. Pay $100 to pushka."

Ages 5 and over.

25656.name: World Pro Tennis Tour
25656.description: In this roll-and-move game, players move around the board taking part in ten major world classic tennis tournaments. Players get money for placing in the tournaments, promoting tournaments, getting TV commercials and endorsements, and finishing with the best record of play. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

25657.name: Equate Junior Tile Set
25657.description:
This tile set contains 176 tiles including whole numbers with more 0s and 1s than the Original Tile Set, fractions with denominator 2, the four basic operations with more addition and subtraction tiles than multiplication and division tiles and equal symbols. Packaged in two ziplock bags. Recommended for ages 6 and up.

Expands

Equate

25658.description:
From the publisher's website:

This expansion set for the American Megafauna evolutionary game adds new technology, venom, and marine adaptations. It also expands the game into a five-player game, with the addition of the Proto-Croc player, aka “Arizonasaurus”.

This is an expansion set, you will need American Megafauna to play, preferably the second edition.

Expansion set contents:


A booklet that includes errata, alternate starting biomes, and a personal commentary on the significance of the game to today’s events,
A new creature sheet, along with a card and tents for the new fifth player,
New cards: 31 new DNA cards, 9 new biome cards, 4 new catastrophe cards, and 2 new genotype cards.


Expands:

American Megafauna
25658.name: American Megafauna (second edition) Expansion Set

25659.name: Armada
25659.description: This game comes from a company called Chad Valley and was produced in the mid 1920's. The object of the game was to shoot down and therefore sink your opponents sailing ships using balls fired from two working lead cannons.

25660.description:
All the thrills of baseball without leaving your house.

Speed Baseball uses a combination of cards and a die roll to determine the outcome of each hitter. As well as normal play each person has 3 special actions a game that they can take which have a huge affect on the game. These actions range from pinch hitting to a double play.

The game be downloaded for free from the publishers official website http://www.spunkychicken.com/baseball.shtml
25660.name: Speed Baseball

25661.name: Air Race
25661.description: Air Race is a game involving the delivery of mail around the world in the shortest time possible. The game is for 2 - 4 players. Each player uses destination cards in order to determine where one needs to deliver the mail to. Finishing ones deliveries in the shortest amount of time is the goal of the game. Rolling the dice is the method of movement. This is a Chad Valley game from the mid 1930's

25662.name: Millionaire
25662.description: A board game for up to seven players, the object of the game for one of the players to become a Millionaire. The journey of players around the board is subject to advantage and penalty squares and a pack of playing cards with similar subject matter. the game features a lovely board loaded with period illustrations. The game was produced by Wm. Sessions Ltd.of York, England sometime in the early 1940s.

25663.name: Rolo-Boko
25663.description: Unusual game consisting of six character heads and two lithographed Yo-Yo style discs. The object is to place the disc over the head and roll it it round the perimeter back to the lithographed bee start position without it falling off. That task is a pretty difficult thing to do. Characters are Jack (sailor HMS Watt.), Punch (Punch & Judy), Joey (Clown), Algy, Bertie and Colonel Bogey (cartoon or comic characters).

25664.name: Py
25664.description:
From the box:

"Py is a new exciting math game.
For all levels from kindergarten to college
Exercise your creativity and sharpen your mind
Great for family entertainment
Play by yourself or with others
Build a dazzling 3-D pyramid while you play
Intensity piles up as the game progresses
Create your own versions of the game"

Contents include:
Wooden board
2 holding blocks
Numbered wooden pegs
2 dice

Instructions include rules for five games: Connect color, Plus-Minus, All Operations, Combinations, & Squares.

Made in Bettendorf, Iowa.

Home Page: http://pygame.com/

25665.description:
As the Avalanche Press website explains, Red Russia uses a similar system to Soldier Kings in simulating the Russian Civil War. Players represent up to four factions: the Reds (Communists), Siberian Whites (monarchists), Southern Whites, or Northern Whites. Each turn represents three months, and the game begins in Summer of 1918 and concludes, should one player not win outright, in the Spring 1921 turn. This 3-4 hour game thus lasts a maximum of twelve turns.

Players command infantry and cavalry armies, and for some factions fleets and aircraft. Leaders assist these units in movement and combat over land areas and sea zones. Each land area is rated for the amount of money and manpower it generates each turn. Manpower represents not just fresh recruits for armies, but also the things made with human labor: food, uniforms, weapons and so on. Factions thus use manpower to rebuild forces, and money to finance their actions. Combat is conducted by rolling dice, one for each attack factor, with hits reducing them in strength or eliminating them outright. A good general lets you roll more dice. Each area is also rated for its garrison strength; to capture it, you have to defeat the garrison troops through siege (in addition to driving off any enemy armies there).

Finally, to keep the game from becoming too "Risk"-like, players can play various event cards. Having the ability to fight through adversity makes one a powerful adversary in Red Russia.
25665.name: Red Russia

25666.name: Where's the Dough?
25666.description:
This is primarily an educational tool to structure learning about starting and operating a business. It is not intended to be played in a single sitting, but instead paces, adds random elements, and "keeps score" over the span of a entire business or economics class. It was created by a student group at North Central College in Naperville IL ("...just 29 miles from downtown Chicago." per to game).

Students will create business goal for a cookie making firm, eventually describing marketing, financial, and operational plans. The game tests these plans through the use of randomly drawn cards that create variations and alternatives for the students to cope with and learn from.

The production value is decent, with a fully mounted folding board. The documentation included with the game is excellent. There is a teacher's manual, blank and example business plans, blank cards of all four types to allow customization, and an instruction sheet for playing the game.

25667.name: In Search of Identity
25667.description:
"An Exciting Way to Discover Black Heritage!"

This is a well-produced game that tests the players' knowledge of famous black people, black history, and black culture, with a predominantly American focus. The primary goal of the game is to score points by answering questions on the above subjects, with individual turn actions keyed by a basic roll-and-move mechanic.

The significant twist in the game is that each player takes one of twenty cards sets, each set consisting of 11 cards. Ten are clue cards related to a single black historical figure or celebrity. Another card in each set has the person's name and picture. During the game, the other players have the opportunity privately or publicly hear the clues and try to guess the character. The clues are divulged based on the players answers to toss-up questions on cards ("Words of Wisdom" and "Go Back to your Roots"), drawn when they land on the corresponding squares. Other squares allow free guessing of secret identities, answering questions for additional points, and other more typical roll-and-move actions. Points for answers/guesses are tallied on paper for as the game progresses.

This game appears to have a good balance between movement, deduction, and trivia mechanics. An unfortunate rule is that players who have their secret identities guessed are then out of the game, so it would help to have the most obscure figure possible. (There were two of twenty I was completely unfamiliar with, and a couple more I needed a clue to recognize.)

There will not be much replay after all the IDs have been used...but if that happens the game will have largely succeeded in it primary educational goal.

25668.name: XIG: The Sorcerers Sword
25668.description:
In this original and distinct game expanding from the world of XIG: The Four Elements, players challenge each other to complete a Sorcerers Sword while battling to control the rings of the four elements: Earth, Fire, Water, and Air.
Each player begins the game with 36 shuffled tiles. Each tile is potentially a piece of their sword which requires only 30 tiles to complete. Every tile represents a different Sorcerer. Specific Sorcerers allow the players to cast spells as the tiles are put into play, as well as displace their opponent's tiles.
Tiles can be linked together in many combinations as long as they don't break elemental rules (for example: Water cannot be linked above fire since fire would then be extinguished). Element combinations allow the players to obtain, or steal rings which can give the controlling player certain game advantage.
The first player to complete their sword wins.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Golden Geek Best Children's Board Game Nominee
2007 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee
2007 Mensa Select Winner
2008 Boardgames Australia Awards Best International Game Nominee
2008 Vuoden Peli Family Game of the Year Nominee
2011 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee
2011 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
2011 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
2011 Spiel des Jahres Nominee
2011 Spiel des Jahres Winner
2012 Hungarian Board Game Award Nominee
2013 Guldbrikken Best Family Game Nominee
2015 Gouden Ludo Nominee
25669.description:
The abstract game of Qwirkle consists of 108 wooden blocks with six different shapes in six different colors. There is no board, players simply use an available flat surface.

Players begin the game with six blocks. The start player places blocks of a single matching attribute (color or shape but not both) on the table. Thereafter, a player adds blocks adjacent to at least one previously played block. The blocks must all be played in a line and match, without duplicates, either the color or shape of the previous block.

Players score one point for each block played plus all blocks adjacent. It is possible for a block to score in more than one direction. If a player completes a line containing all six shapes or colors, an additional six points are scored. The player then refills his hand to six blocks.

The game ends when the draw bag is depleted and one player plays all of his remaining blocks, earning a six point bonus. The player with the high score wins.
boardgameversion: G3 / Schmidt / Corfix / Compaya multi-lingual edition with Spiel des Jahres mark
Schmidt Spiele multilingual edition 2011 with SdJ
25669.name: Qwirkle
boardgamepodcastepisode: 28 Games Later: Qwirkle
BGTG 115 - Spiel des Jahres, Then & Now
BGTG 66 - Dec. 8, 2006 - Thanksgiving Leftovers (Qwirkle, Winner's Circle, Harry's Grand Slam Baseball, Hyle7, Make Five) & Feedback
Cubepushers - Episode 4: Let the Nerd-Rage Flow
DJ3: Qwirkle (2006) Susan McKinley Ross
Durchgespielt – Spiel des Jahres 2011: Qwirkle
Ep 035 – Spiel des Jahres predictions and discussion
Garrett's Games 352 - Qwirkle Travel and Le Havre 2-Player
Garrett's Games 388 - Expansions and Alternatives: Qwirkle, Catan, and Carcassonne
Giochi da spiaggia, ed. 2016 – Il Dado Incantato #8
Ludology Episode 51 - 50 for 50, Part 2
Podcast #043 - Guia de compras y recomendaciones de juegos de mesa 2011 Parte 1
Spiele-Podcast Nr. 113: Qwirkle - Spiel des Jahres 2011 (Schmidt Spiele)
The Dice Men Cometh – Episode 158
The Spiel #50 - It's In The Bag
The Spiel at Essen 2011 - Susan McKinley Ross
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 54!!!!

25670.name: Resistance Is Not Futile: Warsaw 1943
25670.description:
(From Firefight Games website)
"Resistance is not Futile" covers the Insurrection of the Warsaw Ghetto in April 1943. With most of its remaining population already having endured years of privation and growing squalor, mass deportations, and learning that soon the Nazis would be back to send the remainder to Concentration Camps, an insurrection broke out on the eve of Adolf Hitler’s birthday. Local SS commander, Jurgen Stroop, believed the troops he had on-hand would make for a quick end to this impudent act of defiance by the Jews and the Polish Home Army members who choose to rise up against the Third Reich. His underestimation of the Jewish and Polish defenders was a costly mistake, as the fight lasted for weeks and cost the Germans and their fascist allies dearly."

Firefight Games had to suspend sales of this game temporarily after it prompted wild accusations of antisemitism against the designer. According to a post on Consimworld by Paul Rohrbaugh, sales have since resumed after consultations with lawyers, while legal proceedings are going ahead with the slanderers.

The game has also been sent to the Curator of the Holocaust Museum for review.

Map scale: 100 yards per inch
Counter scale: squad/platoon
Game turn: 2 or 3 days

25671.name: Casino Six
25671.description:
Casino Six
The ultimate game of chance.

Casino Six brings the challenge and excitement of six real casino games into you home. It's family fun for adults and older children - all in a simplified form, so even beginners can play. For more experienced players (and bold novices!) authentic Craps and Roulette layouts can be found. Games can be expanded to your liking.

Players advance through the Casino, trying their luck and testing their skill at six games in the following order:
Slots
Blackjack
Keno
Craps
Poker
Roulette

The object is to be the player who bankrupts all the others, winning all of the money.

25672.name: Words Worth
25672.description:
The game contains 100 letter tiles, 50 category tiles, a large 'bucket' to hold the tiles, and a 60 second sand timer.

Before each round, players draw 8 letter tiles from the bucket. A category is drawn.

Players have 60 seconds to form a word from their tiles. A bonus is awarded if the word relates to the category drawn.

A typical game last 10 rounds.

25673.description:
Another expansion to the well known trivia game.
The questions all deal with topics like geography, destinations and other things related to traveling.

The box contains:
- 2400 questions and answers on
- 400 cards in
- 2 plastic boxes.
25673.name: Trivial Pursuit: Holiday Edition

boardgamehonor: 2008 Games Magazine Best New Advanced Strategy Game Winner
25674.description:
In this game, you play a powerful lord and his faithful companion engaged in a fight for influence throughout time. The game proceeds simultaneously over three different periods. You start the game in the Middle Ages, on the first of the three game boards (that of the commanderies). With 4 action cards in hand per turn, you have seven turns in which to develop your domains by building various types of military, religious, and civil buildings. Depending on their size, certain buildings are moved in time, which means that they are transferred to the same place on the priories board (Renaissance period) and on the brotherhoods board (modern period), in ruins for military and religious buildings (castles, abbeys…).

Thanks to the watch makers' invention, and with enough money, you can make your two adventurer pawns travel in time… Because if the construction of certain buildings can be profitable, taking over domains on the various boards is essential, since it will allow you to earn bonuses on the 4th and 7th turns and to move ahead of your opponents.

Playing with time is not without consequences, and it can produce surprising results! To give just one example, an abbey created on the priories board could be destroyed by a castle built later in the game in the same place but on the commanderies board, and then moved to the other board… The abbey finally never existed!

On the 4th and 7th turns, each controlled domain generates profits for the players depending on the board. On the the commanderies board, a player who controls a domain militarily, i.e. the one with the biggest military building, will receive the value of the civil buildings in this domain in profits. On the priories board, it is the religious control that will be taken into account. On the brotherhoods board, the players who have best populated the civil buildings and restored the ruins will secure the best profits.

The possibility of destroying and regrouping buildings to unite or divide domains provides a strong and permanent level of interaction between the players.
25674.name: Khronos
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 22 – Khronos
The Spiel #122 - Eric Clapton's Underwear

25675.name: Négoces
25675.description: Negotiate with the other players the purchase and the sale of goods and become the Great Negotiator. Each player is a merchant. At the beginning, it holds the monopoly of 2 goods and has gold coins. To gain, it must hold 8 different goods and at least 10 parts. For that, exchanges are organized between the players. Simple and original game, Négoces will astonish you by his subtlety. In this play the chance never intervenes, only your direction of the negotiation will enable you to gain.

25676.name: Motomix
25676.description:
Motomix is a quiz game where all aspects of the long history of motorcycles and motorcycling are covered by over 1.000 questions about bike manufacturers, legendary machines, technological developments, mechanics, sporting events, the great champions...giving you the chance to test your knowledge and discover a wealth of anecdotes !

Then you have to find the best route around the track and the best approach to tackle the different obstacles (double-hump, triple-hump, whoops, table...) in the best conditions...at several points in the race you will be able to slam across your opponents' path with a well-timed block pass and force them to reduce speed by answering correctly to the questions!

25677.description:
From the publisher's website:

Once again, our unfortunate friends find themselves foreigners trapped within the frightful Fortress Furor of the fanged Prince Fieso who would, with felicity, see them flounder and faint. These fine fighters could feasibly face their finish in this forbidding fortification, whose fearsome floors even now flow frighteningly from beneath their feet as the famished Furunkulus forages the fringes, fixing to feast on the foreigners’ flesh. Forthwith, must our fighters fashion their flight from this foulest of fates! But what’s this? By the light of their fallow and flickering flares, our friends find the depths fraught with the most furious of fiends and the fiercest of freaks! With fleet feet, the fearless foreigners follow these ferocious fellows through the fortress, with its multifarious footpaths and their frustrating forks, forging fervently forward toward freedom and fame. Our fighters must not falter from whatever feud or fracas would foil their function: to finally furnish the forlorn Faerie Fabula her freedom from feckless Fieso’s fists!

Theme
Formidable Foes is a light-hearted dungeon crawl. The players all take the role of heroes competing with each other to amass the greatest hoard of treasure. They do this by exploring the dungeon and fighting monsters.

Goal
The goal is to collect as much gold as possible. The winner is the richest player.

Gameplay
On each turn, a player either moves twice; moves once and fights a monster; or collects 'power tokens' which allow a player to improve their dice rolls in subsequent turns. In the early part of the game, the monsters are fairly weak and easily defeated. Defeating a monster increases a character's 'wisdom' which allows them to fight and defeat ever-harder monsters. Fighting monsters involves rolling a dice and then adding power tokens to improve the roll if required.
25677.name: Formidable Foes

25679.name: Fame Game
25679.description:
From the box description:
Race to Stardom with the "Fame" gang. Based on the popular TV show.

"You've got big dreams, you want fame."

And right here is where you start playing.

You and your friends race through the N.Y. School of the Arts collecting points as you move towards graduation.

Ages 6 years to adult.

25683.name: Whammy! with Tic - Tac - Toe
25683.description:
This is a children's game.

The goal is to score points by getting strings of 3, 4, or 5 of your color in a straight line. The game comes with a board with the scoring for both variations written right on the playing surface.

boardgamedesigner: Wong & The Design Office, San Francisco
25684.name: Scrosswords
25684.description:
From the back cover of the box:

The Fast Game of Vocabulary, Luck, & Action

Love playing with words but think word games are too slow?
Then start your mental engines and get ready for Scrosswords, the "un-bored" word game with no board, no waiting, and no end to the fun.
Each round pits one player against all others in a race to discover words in random letter tiles. When you're the Wordsmith, you roll five dice: The black dice determine how many tiles you get - from 4 to 24 - and the red die gives you a chance at a bonus category.

The timer starts as soon as you flip over your tiles. You've got 2 minutes and 30 seconds to form as many words as possible, crossword-style, and earn points for them. Meanwhile all other players - the Scavengers - are furiously writing down all the words you're missing. At the end of the round, tally up you points and see whose words are worth the most!
It takes a combination of luck, skill, and fast reflexes to score big at Scrosswords. And because every turn is different and everyone plays at once, the excitement never slows down!

25685.description:
One of the Avalon Hill games of the early 1990s was Blackbeard, a pirate game totally different from any others available because it simulated the actual life and careers of historical pirates, and how they went about their chosen professions.

Richard Berg has now taken the original and redesigned it, almost entirely, to bring it into line with what gamers like to see and play these days. All those pirates you loved - Black Bart Roberts, Long Ben Avery, Ned Lowe, L'Ollonais, and, of course, Edward Teach (Blackbeard) - 23 in all, are still there, as are the King's Commissioners sent out to stop them. However, the entire play system has been overhauled, and the result is a game that highlights and specializes in player interaction, with almost no down time for any players.

Players represent individual pirates, using them to gain Victory Points by amassing booty and, even more importantly, earning Notoriety for their dastardly deeds. Seizing merchants with cargo ranging from useless paper to the monumental treasure of the Mughal emperors, attacking and sacking ports, fighting storms and scurvy, seeking safe haven in infamous pirate ports such as Tortuga and Madagascar, and, hopefully, using Letters of Marque to retire successfully.

And while the player is doing this, all of the other players, at the same time, are playing their cards and seizing opportunities to stop the pirates. There is a constant interplay among players, and you never know what is going to happen when you set out to do something.

We've simplified movement (no more hexes) and ship battles, we've expanded the use of Royal Navy warships, we've even added individual hostages! (Yes, there is a "Governor's Daughter".)
25685.name: Blackbeard
boardgamepodcastepisode: Guns, Dice, Butter Episode IX: Nov 18, 2012
Show #3.5 Session Report: GMT's Blackbeard
제85회 협력게임, Black Beard
제86회 청취자 투고, 만취게임 - Blackbeard

25687.description:
description of the game from LudoArt:

Fragile was designed by Czarné, who also did the graphics for it. A whole slew of crates have arrived at the wharf in Shanghai. Now, this highly fragile cargo must be brought to safety in one's own warehouse as quickly as possible. Problem is, the warehouses are all over the place. Plans are perpetually sent askew, since foreign Chinese workers will often push your crate out from under your nose. Each player controls a team of Chinese workers. Who will be the first to use his team to fill his warehouse with crates - that is, get the most points for fragile cargo? Fragile will please the mind and eye of any strategist.

In a game variant, a little more luck can be added to help things along.
25687.name: Fragile

25688.name: Monopoly: Atlanta Braves
25688.description:
From Publisher:

The Monopoly Brand proudly presents the Atlanta Braves™ Collector’s Edition of America’s favorite board game. Braves fans now have the opportunity to buy, sell and trade Braves players, coaches, announcers and team icons. Features legendary Braves players like Hank Aaron, John Smoltz and Andruw Jones. Includes six collectible pewter tokens: Braves hat, batter, pitcher, ball in glove, Georgia dog and the Atlanta Braves tomahawk. With some of the all-time greatest Major League Baseball players and a bright future ahead, the Braves continue to make for exciting play in this timeless game of risk taking and deal making. Bankrupt your opponents in a quest to own the Braves.

25689.name: Monopoly: Boston Red Sox
25689.description:
From the Publisher:

The MONOPOLY® Brand proudly presents the Boston Red Sox™ Collector’s Edition of America’s favorite board game. We bring Red Sox fans the best of the Red Sox – players, coaches and team icons. Featuring Ted Williams, Jason Varitek and Carlton Fisk, and collectible pewter tokens including a Red Sox hat, batter, pitcher, World Series trophy, Sox and ball in glove. This MONOPOLY Game is a must-have collectible for the die-hard Red Sox fan. This collector’s game captures and brings to life the Red Sox greatest accomplishments including the 1918 and 2004 World Series Championships. Home to some of the most accomplished players in Major League Baseball®, the Red Sox continue to make for exciting play in this classic game of risk taking and deal making

25690.name: Sting
25690.description:
This is a 'press your luck' kind of dice game...

Each person is given two dice (with numbers 1 to 4, two sides have 1's, two sides have 2's), and some chips to begin. Some chips are left in the center to form the 'pot'.

On a person's turn, he/she begins by rolling the 2 dice, examining the sum of the two numbers.

If they add up to 2, that person has been 'stung', and a chip is given to the pot, and play passes to the next player.

If they add up to 8, that person has rolled a 'sting', and gets to take 2 chips from the pot, and play passes to the next player.

If they add up to anything else, that person MUST roll again and try to roll a number equal to, or higher, than the sum of the first roll. At this point ANYONE else playing can also try to roll a sum equal to or higher. Anyone who succeeds gets 2 chips from the pot, anyone who fails loses one. If the active player ends up going it alone, and succeeds, his/her winnings are doubled. Losings are never doubled.

Play ends at a specific number of chips or when the pot is exhausted.

25691.description:
Based on the hit 1960's television series.

From the box:
During the game, a player moves his Pedestrian on the outside path until he reaches a corner space with a Batmobile. He then immediately operates the Batmobile out of the corner space along either path of circles. On his next turn, the player moves his rented Batmobile over the squares of the grid, trying to capture Villains. If the Batmobile goes off the grid (6x6 squares), it jumps to the nearest corner space and the player's turn ends. On his next turn, he moves the Pedestrian again toward another corner with a Batmobile, and another try at capturing more Villains, faster than his opponents.

The object of the game is to be the first player to capture six (6) different Villains.
25691.name: The Batman Game

25692.description:
On The Green Golf is a hole-by-hole simulation that brings together the detail of a shot-by-shot game with the quick-play of a round-by-round game.

Golfers are rated for their ability to reach greens in regulation, going for the green, sand saves, and eagles. Holes are rated for their effect on scoring, and have been painstakingly rated to account for the major hazards and features that will challenge golfers.

The game includes an optional (but highly recommended) weather system that modifies dice rolls for weather and wind, pin placements, and user setting of rough (although a die roll could also make that determination).

There is also a QuickPlay system that allows players the ability to play a round in just three dice rolls for each golfer. This gives players the opportunity to complete entire tournaments in a reasonable amount of time.

And the best part about the QuickPlay system is that you can mix-and-match the three QuickPlay options (full round, nine-hole version, and six-hole version) to QuickPlay some of each round, then switch to the regular game to play out exciting finishes.

The game comes with the following:

-- 2005 men's golfer set (202 cards)
-- Six courses (Augusta, Baltusrol, The Belfry, Pinehurst, Sawgrass, and St. Andrews)
-- Weather and Course Condition Cards
-- Suspense Charts
-- QuickPlay Charts for all six courses
-- Rules

The game is available in two formats:

1) E-Game Format via Hot Stove Games: We send you the files, you print the components using your own equipment or local print shop. E-mail us at hotstovegames@yahoo.com for ordering information.

2) Printed Format via Downey Games: You receive a full-color, printed version of the game with die-cut golfer and course cards, sent to you in a sturdy storage box. Check out the game under "Board Games" at www.downeygames.com
25692.name: On The Green Golf

25693.description:
Kings & Castles is a strategic fantasy wargame. From 2-6 players each take one of the kingdoms on the map, are given a king, a prince, a castle, and points to build units, and try to conquer as much territory as possible. At the end of the game victory points are assessed primarily for owned manors and castles.

At the beginning of each game year players receive production points from their manors and spend them on units - in the basic game there are 21 different units that can be purchased, including siege engines and the like. Players then plot the movement of their forces for the 15 turns constituting the year. Orders can be changed under certain circumstances (e.g., if your kingdom is invaded).

Combat is conducted using a deck of cards, with the number drawn for each side being determined by their strengths.

There are some optional rules, including rules for ambushes, capturing enemy leaders, a 7th and 8th player taking the roles of pirates or bandits, and wizards, a new type of unit who can cast a variety of spells and create magical creatures such as dragons.

The game components are:
26-page rulebook
17" x 21.75" color map
50 combat resolution cards
112 very small cardboard chits (16 each in 7 colors, lettered A-P)
2 small black and white copies of the map
2 movement programming sheets
2 dice
25693.name: Kings & Castles
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGTG 107 - Handcrafted Games (with Lincoln Damerst and Greg Wilzbach)

25694.name: Conquest
25694.description:
Conquest is a strategic space exploration and conquest (naturally) game for 2-4 players. Each player starts in a system at a corner of the map and expands outward from there.

Each player represents a different spacefaring race/organization - the Terrans, the Olso Empire, the Federation (changed to the Confederation in the second edition), and the Tholians (changed to the Lothians in the second edition). Each has a different set of units they can build, with varying capabilities - ships are rated for space combat, ground (bombardment) combat, drive system, and what kind of damage they take from the various combat results.

When a star is explored a card is drawn which determines the class of the inhabitable world found there and, if inhabited, its attitude to each of the players. In addition to the attitude the value of each kind of planet varies by player.

There are three different long-range movement systems in the game - warp drive, jump drive (similar to warp drive but much less accurate), and stargates, which have to be built and carried to where you want to use them. Each player uses one of the three systems for their ships.

The second edition, in addition to changing the names of two of the races, changed some of the ship designs which were similar to Star Trek and Star Wars ships. It also changed the name of the game to The Conquest and Exploration of Space.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee
25695.description:
Chopstick Dexterity MegaChallenge 3000 is a simple but frantic dexterity game in which the object is to collect the most tokens by using chopsticks to pick up the object shown on the token. The theme is presented as a TV game show intended to promote the use of chopsticks among Japanese youth.

To set up, place 25 objects — which comes in five colors and five shapes — in a plastic bowl. Shuffle the tokens face-down, then draw one and reveal it. Tokens show either a specific object or a generic shape in all colors; to win this token, players simultaneously compete to get wooden pieces represented on it. Using only chopsticks, players try to grab specific wooden shapes or colors from a large bowl to their personal target dish. In the three-player game, all players must grab all of the pieces which are either the shape or the color shown on the token. Whoever grabs the most objects wins the token. In a tie, the tied player with the exact shape shown on the token wins.

In the two-player game, the players must grab only the exact piece shown on the token. After each round, the token is awarded and the objects returned to the bowl to start the next round. Play continues until a certain number of tokens are won.

In the solo version, the player is given 75 seconds to remove the pieces from the bowl with their chopsticks to place each piece in a grid with each row given to one of the shapes and each column given to one of the colors.
25695.name: Chopstick Dexterity MegaChallenge 3000
boardgamepodcastepisode: MN 0057 Ryan Bruns of Mayday Games
The Spiel #68 - That's A Wrap - 2008 Holiday Gift Guide
The Vintage Gamer Special #04: Origins 2008 Interviews

25697.name: Wok & Roll
25697.description:
Contents: 1 Wok, 4 Chopsticks, 4 Bowls, Play Food
Object of the game: When the wok is empty, the player with the most food is the winner.

Requires 2 AA batteries. Turn switch on and the wok will start spinning. Use your chopsticks to pick up food from the wok and place into your bowl.

25698.name: Auto-Go
25698.description: Motor Car Race Game from the early 1930's. The game comes with a four-fold board which has early race car illustrations. The game has four cast lead race car playing pieces. This is a two to six player game . Players spin and then go around the track avoiding penalty places if they can. The game was published by H.P.Gibson & Sons.

25699.name: Farm Lotto
25699.description:
From the box:

CONTENTS: 4 Playing Boards, 36 Cards.

HOW TO PLAY: Each player takes a playing board and the smaller cards are placed face down on the table. The youngest player starts by turning over one of the cards and matching it with one of the characters on his playing board. If he cannot, he leaves the card face upwards on the table. The next player may then take this card or selects another. Play continues; should a player turn over a card the he already has, play passes to the next player.

The winner is the first player to cover all his characters on his playing board.

FOR OLDER CHILDREN: If a player picks up a card he does not need he replaces the card face downwards on the table. The other players then have to remember where that card was replaced if they need that particular character.

25702.description:
"Six Men's Morris is played in the same way as Nine Men's Morris, with two changes, the first is that each player has six men and the second is that it is played on [a modified] board (which is similar to that used by Nine Men's Morris, except it lacks the outer set of lines)."

Variation: Five Men's Morris is played on the same modified board, but using 5 men on a side instead of six.
25702.name: Six Men's Morris

25703.name: Blackout
25703.description:
Inside the box:

- 4 boards, each with the letters of the alphabet
- 100 subject cards
- timer
- 110 chips

Idea of the game:

To fill one's own board as quick as possible. Player gets a subject and timer starts. Player tries to say as many words as possible from the given subject in given time.
